name: Egyptian Mythology
tagline: The Divine Wisdom of the Nile Valley
description: Uncover the mysteries of ancient Egypt, where gods walk as animals and the afterlife awaits all.
overview: Egyptian mythology represents one of the longest-lived religious traditions in human history, spanning over 3,000 years from the Early Dynastic Period (c. 3100 BCE) to the Roman conquest (30 BCE). This sophisticated mythological system features gods who manifest in animal forms, an elaborate afterlife journey through the Duat underworld, the solar theology of Ra's daily rebirth, the Osirian resurrection mysteries, and the fundamental concept of Ma'at - cosmic order, truth, and justice. Egyptian religion was deeply integrated with kingship, as pharaohs served as living Horus and deceased Osiris. The mythology evolved through different periods and cult centers, with Heliopolis, Memphis, Thebes, and Hermopolis each developing distinct creation myths and theological systems.

sections.title: Creation Myths & Cosmogony
sections.body:
Ancient Egypt developed multiple creation myths centered at different cult cities:

**Heliopolitan Cosmogony (Heliopolis):** In the beginning was Nun - the primordial waters of chaos. From Nun arose Atum (or Atum-Ra), the self-created god who stood on the primeval mound (benben). Atum produced Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture) through masturbation or sneezing. They birthed Geb (earth) and Nut (sky), who in turn produced the great Ennead: Osiris, Isis, Set, Nephthys, and (sometimes) Horus.

**Memphite Theology (Memphis):** Ptah created the world through thought (in his heart) and speech (on his tongue), making him the ultimate creator god whose word brought all things into being.

**Hermopolitan Ogdoad (Hermopolis):** Eight primordial deities (four frog-headed gods and four serpent-headed goddesses) representing chaos, darkness, the abyss, and infinity emerged from Nun to create the cosmic egg from which Ra hatched.

**Theban Theology (Thebes):** Amun as the hidden, self-created god who brought forth all other deities and the cosmos itself.

sections.title: Solar Theology & Ra's Journey
sections.body:
The sun god Ra (ğ“‡³) was central to Egyptian cosmology, representing divine kingship, creation, and cosmic order. Each day, Ra travels across the sky in his solar barque (boat), bringing light and life to the world:

**Dawn (Khepri ğ“†£):** Ra rises as Khepri, the scarab beetle, symbolizing rebirth and transformation.

**Noon (Ra-Horakhty ğ“…ƒ):** At his zenith, Ra shines as Ra-Horakhty ("Horus of the Horizon"), representing full divine power.

**Dusk (Atum ğ“‡‹ğ“ğ“ğ“›):** As evening approaches, Ra becomes Atum, the aged form approaching rest.

**Night Journey (Amduat):** Through the twelve hours of night, Ra's barque travels through the Duat (underworld), battling the chaos serpent Apophis/Apep. The dead pharaoh joins Ra in this eternal cycle, ensuring the sun's rebirth each dawn.

This solar cycle represented the eternal battle between order (Ma'at) and chaos (Isfet), with Ra's nightly victory ensuring the world's continued existence.

sections.title: The Osiris Myth: Death & Resurrection
sections.body:
The Osiris myth formed the foundation of Egyptian afterlife beliefs:

Osiris (ğ“Š¨ğ“¹ğ“€­), the good king, ruled Egypt with his sister-wife Isis (ğ“Š¨ğ“ğ“). His jealous brother Set (ğ“ƒ©ğ“£) murdered Osiris, sealed his body in a coffin, and threw it into the Nile. Isis searched desperately and found the coffin grown into a tree in Byblos. She recovered Osiris's body and hid it in the marshes, but Set discovered it and tore the body into 14 pieces, scattering them across Egypt.

Isis, aided by her sister Nephthys (ğ“Ÿğ“ğ“‚ğ“ğ“), searched for every piece and reassembled Osiris. Using her magical powers and the help of Anubis (ğ“‡‹ğ“ˆ–ğ“Šªğ“…±ğ“ƒ£), god of mummification, Isis revived Osiris long enough to conceive their son Horus (ğ“…ƒğ“€­). Though Osiris could not fully return to life, he became lord of the underworld and judge of the dead.

Horus grew to adulthood and battled Set for the throne of Egypt, eventually triumphing and becoming the divine prototype of the living pharaoh, while every deceased pharaoh became Osiris.

This myth established: mummification practices, the concept of resurrection, the importance of proper burial, and the divine right of kingship.

sections.title: The Afterlife Journey & Judgment
sections.body:
Egyptian afterlife beliefs were among the most elaborate in the ancient world:

**Death & Mummification:** Preservation of the body was essential as the ba (ğ“…¡ soul-personality) and ka (ğ“‚“ life force) needed to reunite with it. Mummification protected the body for eternity.

**Journey Through the Duat (ğ“‡¼ğ“„¿ğ“):** The deceased traveled through the twelve hours of night in the underworld, facing demons, gates, and challenges. Magical spells from the Book of the Dead helped navigate dangers.

**The Weighing of the Heart:** In the Hall of Two Truths, the deceased's heart was weighed against the feather of Ma'at (ğ“™ğ“ğ“) - truth and cosmic order. Anubis performed the weighing while Thoth (ğ“…¤ğ“€­) recorded the result. If the heart was lighter than or equal to the feather, the deceased was justified (maa-kheru) and could enter the Field of Reeds, a paradise mirroring Egypt. If heavier (burdened with sin), the heart was devoured by Ammit, the devourer, leading to complete annihilation.

**The Field of Reeds (Aaru):** A blessed afterlife where the justified dead lived eternally, farming perfect fields, enjoying feasts, and sailing on celestial waters.

**Becoming an Akh (ğ“…œ):** The perfected spirit-form achieved through proper burial rites and magical knowledge, allowing the deceased to move between the worlds of living and dead.

sections.title: Ma'at: Cosmic Order & Truth
sections.body:
Ma'at (ğ“™ğ“ğ“) was the foundational concept of Egyptian civilization - representing truth, justice, cosmic order, balance, and proper conduct:

**As Cosmic Principle:** Ma'at was the fundamental order established at creation, opposed to Isfet (chaos). The king's primary duty was maintaining Ma'at through proper rule and ritual.

**As Goddess:** Ma'at personified as a goddess wearing an ostrich feather (symbol of truth), daughter of Ra, and wife of Thoth.

**As Ethical System:** Living in accordance with Ma'at meant: speaking truth, acting justly, showing compassion, maintaining proper hierarchies, performing rituals correctly, and respecting both gods and humans.

**In Afterlife:** The deceased's heart was weighed against Ma'at's feather - only those who lived by Ma'at could enter paradise.

**Royal Ideology:** Pharaohs "did Ma'at" by maintaining justice, building temples, performing rituals, defeating enemies (chaos), and ensuring prosperity. This divine order connected heaven, earth, and underworld.

sections.title: Animal Forms & Sacred Creatures
sections.body:
Egyptian gods manifested in animal forms, representing divine attributes:

**Falcon (Horus, Ra):** Sky, kingship, divine vision
**Jackal (Anubis, Wepwawet):** Death, mummification, guide of the dead
**Ibis (Thoth):** Wisdom, writing, moon
**Lion/Lioness (Sekhmet, Sphinx):** Royal power, protection, destruction
**Cat (Bastet):** Protection, joy, domesticity
**Crocodile (Sobek):** Nile fertility, pharaonic power
**Cobra (Wadjet):** Royal protection, Lower Egypt
**Vulture (Nekhbet):** Motherhood, Upper Egypt
**Scarab Beetle (Khepri):** Transformation, resurrection, sunrise
**Ram (Amun, Khnum):** Creation, fertility, hidden power

Sacred animals were mummified and buried in vast necropolises, with millions of ibis, cats, crocodiles, and other creatures honoring their divine patrons.

sections.title: Hieroglyphic Magic & Divine Writing
sections.body:
Hieroglyphs (mdw-ná¹¯r, "words of the gods") were not merely writing but held magical power:

**Heka (ğ“›ğ“‚“ğ“›):** The primordial force of magic that existed before creation. Personified as a god, heka empowered both divine and human magic. Priests were "servants of heka."

**Names as Power:** Knowing a being's true name gave power over them. The deceased needed to know the names of underworld demons to pass safely.

**Hieroglyphs as Living:** Written words, especially names and images of gods, were believed to be alive and capable of action. Dangerous hieroglyphs (snakes, enemies) were sometimes drawn incomplete or with knives through them to neutralize their power.

**Sacred Texts:** The Pyramid Texts (oldest religious texts, c. 2400 BCE), Coffin Texts, and Book of the Dead contained spells to ensure safe passage through the afterlife, transformation into various forms, and union with the gods.

sections.title: Primary Sources
items: Pyramid Texts (c. 2400-2300 BCE) - Oldest religious texts, inscribed in pyramids
Coffin Texts (c. 2100-1800 BCE) - Spells inscribed on coffins for afterlife protection
Book of the Dead (c. 1550 BCE onward) - Collection of spells for the deceased
Amduat - 'Book of What is in the Underworld' describing Ra's night journey
Book of Gates - Another underworld text detailing the twelve gates of night
Hymns to Ra - Solar theology and daily worship texts
The Contendings of Horus and Set - Mythological narrative of their conflict
Temple Inscriptions - Hieroglyphic texts from temples throughout Egypt
Papyrus texts - Medical, magical, and religious papyri
